node.title: City urges residents near blazing fertilizer plant to evacuate
node.description: Police in Winston-Salem, North Carolina says there could be an explosion at the site. They said first responders were "pleading" with nearby residents to get out.
node.content: ["The City of Winston-Salem is asking people within one mile of a raging blaze at a fertilizer plant to evacuate due to the possibility of a large explosion.", " WGHP-TV reports that the fire started Monday night at the Weaver Fertilizer Plant. City officials have confirmed small explosions at the plant.", " Firefighters say there is the potential for a large explosion of ammonium nitrate. Winston-Salem Fire Chief Trey Mayo says fire crews \"abandoned\" the fire-fighting operation because of the large volume of ammonium nitrate on-site.", " The building has collapsed as well, and access to the product in the building is restricted, WGHP reported.", " Firefighters couldn't flow enough volume of water to be reasonably certain that they could keep it cool enough to prevent a detonation. The cause of the fire is unknown.", " \"Don't wait for something to happen. Something has happened,\" Mayo said on Twitter. \"Now is the time to get out.\" ", " At around 2 a.m. first responders were driving through the area \"pleading\" with residents to evacuate to safely as the threat of an explosion still loomed, Winston-Salem police tweeted.", " Police said the 4400 block of Cherry Street from North Point Boulevard to Indiana Avenue was closed while emergency crews responded to the fire around 8:20 p.m.", " Wake Forest University released a statement asking some students in off-campus housing to voluntarily evacuate. The university also said it was working on long-term plans for those who don't have an alternative place to go.", " \"The evacuation area around 4440 North Cherry Street has almost 6500 residents or 2,497 households,\" the City of Winston-Salem reported on its Twitter page. ", " People who have evacuated should plan to be away from their homes for up to 48 hours.", " No injuries have been reported.", "For Breaking News & Analysis Download the Free CBS News app"]
